Award.AwardTitle: National Resource Center for Materials Technology Education (MatEdU)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With rapid changes and new developments in nanotechnology, bioscience, corrosion, and green technologies, as well as in more traditional areas of metals, plastics and composites, industry need for qualified and educated technicians who understand the basics of materials technology has grown. As such, it is imperative that educational and training programs keep abreast of these advances and have a resource to identify and articulate the linkages between materials science and manufacturing processes.

The National Resource Center for Materials Technology Education (MatEdU) (www.materialseducation.org) strives to be the focal point where industry, education and community collaborate to meet the materials technology workforce needs. MatEdU partners with high schools, community and technical colleges, and universities, including official partnerships with sixteen 2-year and 4-year institutions, and over thirty-five other collaborators. MatEdU is contributing to the body of knowledge in material science by providing instructional resources, up-to-date core competencies, faculty professional development workshops, and technician education to meet the skill demands of employers. These efforts are especially important as new materials and processes continue to emerge. The expanded use of technology is enabling MatEdU to have broader reach, including to underrepresented populations. Enhanced dissemination of MatEdU products to professional societies, industries, educational institutions, and community organizations is impacting the numbers of educated technicians prepared to enter the workforce in this field that is crucial to U.S. global competitiveness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MatEdU is an internationally recognized NSF ATE National Resource Center for Materials Technology Education. MatEdU provides pioneering leadership, mentorship to the national community, and an openness to connect with strategic partners, while also assisting and guiding others in service of NSF ATE and its mission. With continuous NSF ATE funding since 2005, MatEdU achieved and exceeded its four major goals:

Goal 1:  Expanded the online collection of high-quality instructional resources including competency-based modules, presentations, labs, and demonstrations.

Goal 2:  Introduced interactive online resources to the MatEdU website via social media to improve access to instructional resources, expertise, and professional development.

Goal 3: Disseminated strategies to promote increased website awareness and online engagement, support strategic partnerships, and expand professional development opportunities.

Goal 4:  Leveraged partnerships to achieve strategic scalability of MatEdU resources, while investigating strategies and alternative revenue streams.

 

Intellectual Merits

MatEdU helped address the national need for curriculum and instructional resources in materials technology to strengthen the engineering and advanced manufacturing US workforce. MatEdU provided instructional content, tools, and resources to understand materials technology, advanced manufacturing, and engineering design and production processes. It is essential for STEM students and technicians to understand the nonstop increasing quantity and complexity of materials used in advanced manufacturing industries and related sectors. With research, curricula, flexible delivery options, and validated core competencies in materials technology, MatEdU helped enhance and advance technician education nationally. This in turn helps ensure the US remains globally competitive in advanced materials and manufacturing technologies.

Longstanding, groundbreaking MatEdU initiatives form the framework of impacts the Center has had on materials science technician education and faculty and students nationwide. MatEdU?s merits and contributions include:

1) Providing innovative resources for materials science and additive manufacturing for educators and others supporting technician education.

2) Developing innovative and targeted outreach to Hispanic Serving Institutions and Latino high school students across multiple states (CO, CA, AZ, WA, TX).

3) Exploring innovative and sustainable models of industry partnerships, and other partnerships, such as with national and international credentialing bodies.

4) Serving as a mentor in Mentor-Connect annually and an informal mentor to many potential NSF projects beyond the purview of Mentor-Connect.

5) Participating in the expansion and continuing success of the STEM Guitar Building Institute.

 

Broad Impacts

MatEdU?s leadership, partnerships, engagement, and work products in materials science and additive manufacturing nationally and internationally have helped advance materials science technician education. The Center has put a wide array of STEM digital resources, tools, and models directly into the hands of thousands of educators and students across the US. STEM resource examples from MatEdU include curriculum; research; pedagogies; labs; kits; workshops; handbooks; and teaching/learning support materials. MatEdU has helped expand the awareness of educators and policy makers to global trends, research, technologies, and pedagogies for materials-related technician education. Materials technology and materials science continue to be an area of high growth, development, and applications across many industries. Materials, materials technology education, and preparing materials technology STEM technicians for industries from aerospace to aviation to advanced manufacturing will continue to be in high demand and in the national interest.

 

The work and contributions of MatEdU directly and positively impact educational programs on a national level through connection with partner 2- and 4-year institutions, and many high schools and skills centers. Visitors to the MatEdU website number over 300K, currently tracking over 60k a year since 2018. The extension of MatEdU through collaborations and partnerships with other ATE PIs, Centers, projects, and coordination networks, means even broader impact by ensuring related programs and technologies have access to knowledge, models, and practices in advanced materials and materials technology. Through development and broad dissemination of the core competencies, MatEdU has enhanced and impacted the quality of education in manufacturing processes, as well as engineering design. The more STEM technicians in the US understand the relationships between materials properties and production processes, the better the quality, productivity, and competitiveness.

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2020
Modified by: Imelda E Cossette
